segment.source: Installing and Removing an Application on the MED-V Workspace
segment.target: Installing and Removing an Application on the MED-V Workspace

segment.source: Installing and Removing an Application on the MED-V Workspace
segment.target: Installing and Removing an Application on the MED-V Workspace

segment.source: Installing and Removing an Application on the MED-V Workspace
segment.target: Installing and Removing an Application on the MED-V Workspace

segment.source: Applications that are incompatible with the host operating system can be run in the MED-V workspace and opened in the MED-V workspace in the same manner in which they are opened from the host computer, on the Start menu or by using a localhost shortcut.
segment.target: Applications that are incompatible with the host operating system can be run in the MED-V workspace and opened in the MED-V workspace in the same manner in which they are opened from the host computer, on the Start menu or by using a localhost shortcut.

segment.source: After you have deployed a MED-V workspace, you have several different options available to you for installing and removing applications in the MED-V workspace.
segment.target: After you have deployed a MED-V workspace, you have several different options available to you for installing and removing applications in the MED-V workspace.

segment.source: These options include the following:
segment.target: These options include the following:

segment.source: Using Group Policy
segment.target: Using Group Policy

segment.source: Using an Electronic Software Distribution System
segment.target: Using an Electronic Software Distribution System

segment.source: Using Application Virtualization (APP-V)
segment.target: Using Application Virtualization (APP-V)

segment.source: Updating the Core Image
segment.target: Updating the Core Image

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: To make sure that an installed application is automatically published to the host, install the application on the virtual machine for All Users.
segment.target: To make sure that an installed application is automatically published to the host, install the application on the virtual machine for All Users.

segment.source: For more information about application publishing, see How to Publish and Unpublish an Application on the MED-V Workspace.
segment.target: For more information about application publishing, see How to Publish and Unpublish an Application on the MED-V Workspace.

segment.source: Tip
segment.target: Tip

segment.source: MED-V does not support guest-to-host redirection for content handling, such as double-clicking a Microsoft Word document in Internet Explorer in the MED-V workspace.
segment.target: MED-V does not support guest-to-host redirection for content handling, such as double-clicking a Microsoft Word document in Internet Explorer in the MED-V workspace.

segment.source: Therefore, the required applications, such as Microsoft Word, must be installed in MED-V workspace to provide the default content handling functionality that an end user might expect.
segment.target: Therefore, the required applications, such as Microsoft Word, must be installed in MED-V workspace to provide the default content handling functionality that an end user might expect.

segment.source: Adding and Removing Applications by Using Group Policy
segment.target: Adding and Removing Applications by Using Group Policy

segment.source: You can use Group Policy and Group Policy objects to assign or publish applications to all or some MED-V workspaces in your enterprise.
segment.target: You can use Group Policy and Group Policy objects to assign or publish applications to all or some MED-V workspaces in your enterprise.

segment.source: For assigned applications, when an end user logs on to their computer, the application appears on the Start menu.
segment.target: For assigned applications, when an end user logs on to their computer, the application appears on the Start menu.

segment.source: When they select the new application for the first time, the application installs and is ready for use.
segment.target: When they select the new application for the first time, the application installs and is ready for use.

segment.source: For published applications, the application does not appear on the Start menu.
segment.target: For published applications, the application does not appear on the Start menu.

segment.source: It is only available for the end user to install by using Add or Remove Programs in Control Panel or by opening a file that is associated with the application.
segment.target: It is only available for the end user to install by using Add or Remove Programs in Control Panel or by opening a file that is associated with the application.

segment.source: You can also use Group Policy and Group Policy objects in the same manner to remove applications from the MED-V workspace.
segment.target: You can also use Group Policy and Group Policy objects in the same manner to remove applications from the MED-V workspace.

segment.source: For more information about how to add and remove applications by using Group Policy, see Group Policy Software Installation (http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=195931).
segment.target: For more information about how to add and remove applications by using Group Policy, see Group Policy Software Installation (http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=195931).

segment.source: Adding and Removing Applications by Using an ESD System
segment.target: Adding and Removing Applications by Using an ESD System

segment.source: An electronic software distribution (ESD) system is designed to efficiently deploy software and other information to many different computers over network connections.
segment.target: An electronic software distribution (ESD) system is designed to efficiently deploy software and other information to many different computers over network connections.

segment.source: If your organization uses an ESD system to deploy software, you can use it to add and remove applications on MED-V workspaces just as you add and remove applications on physical computers.
segment.target: If your organization uses an ESD system to deploy software, you can use it to add and remove applications on MED-V workspaces just as you add and remove applications on physical computers.

segment.source: Adding and Removing Applications by Using APP-V
segment.target: Adding and Removing Applications by Using APP-V

segment.source: Microsoft Application Virtualization (App-V) provides the administrative capability to make applications available to end-user computers without having to install the applications directly on those computers.
segment.target: Microsoft Application Virtualization (App-V) provides the administrative capability to make applications available to end-user computers without having to install the applications directly on those computers.

segment.source: You might want to use MED-V and App-V together if, for example, your organization has applications that you sequenced with App-V in Windows XP, and re-sequencing them would delay your migration to Windows 7.
segment.target: You might want to use MED-V and App-V together if, for example, your organization has applications that you sequenced with App-V in Windows XP, and re-sequencing them would delay your migration to Windows 7.

segment.source: You can use MED-V together with App-V to add and remove virtual applications on a deployed MED-V workspace.
segment.target: You can use MED-V together with App-V to add and remove virtual applications on a deployed MED-V workspace.

segment.source: To manage applications in this manner, you must first install the App-V agent on the MED-V guest operating system.
segment.target: To manage applications in this manner, you must first install the App-V agent on the MED-V guest operating system.

segment.source: You can then use App-V in the MED-V workspace to add and remove the virtual applications.
segment.target: You can then use App-V in the MED-V workspace to add and remove the virtual applications.

segment.source: For information about how to install and use App-V, see Application Virtualization (http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=122939).
segment.target: For information about how to install and use App-V, see Application Virtualization (http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=122939).

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: App-V applications that you publish to the MED-V workspace have file-type associations that cannot redirect from the host computer to the guest virtual machine.
segment.target: App-V applications that you publish to the MED-V workspace have file-type associations that cannot redirect from the host computer to the guest virtual machine.

segment.source: However, the end user can still access these file types by clicking File, and then by clicking Open on the published App-V application.
segment.target: However, the end user can still access these file types by clicking File, and then by clicking Open on the published App-V application.

segment.source: To force redirection of those file-type associations, query App-V for mapped file type associations by typing the following at a command prompt in the guest virtual machine: sftmime /QUERY OBJ:TYPE.
segment.target: To force redirection of those file-type associations, query App-V for mapped file type associations by typing the following at a command prompt in the guest virtual machine: sftmime /QUERY OBJ:TYPE.

segment.source: Then, map those file type associations in the host computer.
segment.target: Then, map those file type associations in the host computer.

segment.source: Adding and Removing Applications on the Core Image
segment.target: Adding and Removing Applications on the Core Image

segment.source: Although not considered a MED-V best practice, you can add and remove applications directly on the core image.
segment.target: Although not considered a MED-V best practice, you can add and remove applications directly on the core image.

segment.source: After you have added or removed an application, you can redeploy the MED-V workspace back out to your enterprise just as you deployed it originally.
segment.target: After you have added or removed an application, you can redeploy the MED-V workspace back out to your enterprise just as you deployed it originally.

segment.source: For more information about how to add or remove applications on the core image, see Installing Applications on a Windows Virtual PC Image.
segment.target: For more information about how to add or remove applications on the core image, see Installing Applications on a Windows Virtual PC Image.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: We do not recommend this method of managing applications.
segment.target: We do not recommend this method of managing applications.

segment.source: If you add or remove applications on the core image and redeploy the MED-V workspace back out to your enterprise, first time setup must run again, and any data saved on the virtual machine is lost.
segment.target: If you add or remove applications on the core image and redeploy the MED-V workspace back out to your enterprise, first time setup must run again, and any data saved on the virtual machine is lost.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: Even though an application is installed into a MED-V workspace, you might also have to publish the application before it becomes available to the end user.
segment.target: Even though an application is installed into a MED-V workspace, you might also have to publish the application before it becomes available to the end user.

segment.source: For example, you might have to publish an installed application if the installation did not automatically create a shortcut on the Start menu.
segment.target: For example, you might have to publish an installed application if the installation did not automatically create a shortcut on the Start menu.

segment.source: Likewise, to unpublish an application, you might have to manually remove a shortcut from the Start menu.
segment.target: Likewise, to unpublish an application, you might have to manually remove a shortcut from the Start menu.

segment.source: By default, most applications are published at the time that they are installed, when shortcuts are automatically created and enabled.
segment.target: By default, most applications are published at the time that they are installed, when shortcuts are automatically created and enabled.
